Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the mother needs to prepare for it
Situation2: Handling a dispute between two drivers involved in a minor traffic accident
Story: I sat in my patrol car, the weight of my badge heavy on my chest. The two drivers stood outside, voices rising, each insisting the other was at fault. As a police officer, I was expected to be fair, to listen to both sides and make an honest report. But my mind kept drifting to the home loan repayment looming in two months. My son’s school fees, groceries, the bills—everything depended on me keeping this job and maybe even earning a little extra overtime. One of the drivers, a well-dressed man, quietly slipped a business card into my hand, hinting at a “favor” if I sided with him. My heart pounded. As a mother, I wanted to secure my family’s future, to make sure we never missed a payment. But as an officer, I was sworn to uphold the law, to act with integrity. The two roles pulled at me from opposite sides, and I felt trapped in the middle, unable to move forward.
